No one's going to argue that our freedom has increased over the past 
decade, but how exactly is it that we have 'no freedom left to defend?' On 
the whole, America still is the leader in guaranteeing and upholding basic 
human rights to its citizens.

Look, it's easy to look at cases where the U.S. is clearly violating its 
constitutional principles-- but you have to realize that these instances 
are rare and when they do occur, they usually come with a rationale. In 
other words, U.S. leaders are not simply violating their citizens' freedoms 
for their own benefit as a dictator would.

To claim that America has no freedom left to defend is a bit insulting to 
third-world countries where they *do* virtually have no freedom.

+Erichev Well sweetheart, I was in the desert under both of those

coming across our borders.

You did 1.6 years in the desert while with the air force.  It pretty much 
makes you a rear echelon pogue living in dorms and catering to the needs of 
the pilots while those of us in combat MOS actually were in danger of 
getting shot, mortared and blown to hell.  You probably sat in Dhahran 
shuffling paperwork and packing ejector seat chutes.

Don't give me no shit of what it was like to live in the military while we 
lived in quanset huts, squad bays, shitters with no doors, pissing 3 to a 
pissing stall, tents, shelter halves, out in the cold Japanese winter 
slushy rain for weeks on end and in the rainy desert cold as hell at night 
and hot during the day. 

I doubt you did even half of that in your 20 (+) years.  I kept in mind, I 
signed the contract, it is what I chose just like everyone else.  If the 
military wanted you to have a family they would have issued you one.  Money 
is definitely not a reason to go into the military, but there is a-lot of 
benefit to being there.  When you are not in a combat situation and you 
live as if you were "meant to live", in the rear with the gear is down 
right easy outside of the little busy work BS they made us do.

Because of my wounds, I managed to get forced out... check out the numbers 
on the back of my name you will know why I could no longer operate with leg 
damage among other things.

So yes, there are times  you are treated like a damn kid, but you asked for 
it by signing the papers.  I can guarantee that you did not even begin to 
play the stupid BS games that most combat MOS people in any branch of 
service did.  I know you didn't in the air force because I had family and 
friends that went that route.
